title: Are Apple AirPods worth the money? - Quora

response.answer_text: I didn’t want them. I’m anti-wireless when it comes to my audio. I’ve been using the wired EarPods for a few years now and have found them very pleasant to listen to when corrected by a 20 band EQ and using an audiophile music player that provides 32-bit float high resolution software support. I found them very impressive for $30 once you flatten the frequency response a bit. So my logic for awhile has been “The AirPods and EarPods have a very close acoustic design. I don’t see the benefit in going to the AirPods at their price with the cost being significantly higher.” And what did I end up receiving as a gift this Christmas? You guessed it! A pair of Apple AirPods. I didn’t jump on using them right away. Once I was back home at my apartment, I finally decided to set them up. Once out of the box and charged, I started testing tracks. I noticed the sound was actually a bit better than the wired version! Then I tweaked the EQ a bit more. It got even better! The sound was noticeably more open than the wired version with a clearer midrange and better low frequency response. They could handle a slight boost in low frequencies where the wired version had to be taken down a bit to keep from muddying up the sound slightly. Then, once they broke in a little bit they sounded even better! Now if Audio quality isn’t super important to you, let’s talk about using them. So far my experience using them has been great. I’m coming to appreciate the convenience of wireless headphones. The charging case is a very nice design. The pods drop in and stay put with magnets and charge them when they are low enough. As long as your Bluetooth is on, they will instantly connect every time once you put them in your ears. If you open the charging case near the phone, it will also connect independently so it can tell you the battery life of the charging case. So if I go to pull out my pods with BT on, once the lid opens an image appears on the screen indicating the battery life of both the case and pods. The image for the case disappears when you close the lid. When you place the pods in your ears, a pleasant tone comes out informing you they are connected. I have had no issues with connection cutting out and the range is surprising. Battery life is very good and I’m just charging the case now after a week and a half out and about. If you are the type to leave your headphones in your ears all day, you will be charging the pods and case more often. I only take mine out when I plan to listen to music or take a conference call. I thought the price wasn’t worth it at first, but my mind has been changed. The overall quality is very impressive. And to all the people who crap on Apple’s prices, these are actually a fair deal. I mean think about how much technology is packed into each tiny AirPod? You have a lithium ion battery, accelerometers, infrared sensors and the W1 processor in that tiny shell. The pod also needs amplification. And let’s not forget the entire headphone driver itself. The W1 processor is really what differentiates the AirPods from other BlueTooth headphones. They are very smart headphones that are very easy to pair and know how to conserve battery. I can honestly say $160 is a fair price for these given the technology and quality they provide. Oh and if the EarPods fit nicely in your ears, you won’t have to worry about the AirPods falling out. Mine haven’t gone anywhere…..yet.

Q: Are Apple AirPods worth the money? Two things to consider : 1 - What does money mean to you? How much do you have available to spend, and what to you think is expensive? 2 - What do you want or need from the Airpods? Do you want to look cool in an Apple product, matches your phone, latest ‘High Tech’ from a brand name? Or do you want HiFi sound a a great quality audio component without a care of what it looks like or the fashion statement? Without those two considerations made clear it is lt to give an answer that suits your intentions. From a purely audio quality, Airpods are very poor audio products. The sound quality is not what I would expect for their cost, and Apple really should and could have done a lot better. It is clear in Apple’s acquisition of the beats company that they have little if any regard for sound quality. Apple always overprices it’s products and keeps very tight control over compatible products of other manufacturers to maintain control over it’s market share. By having such a low audio quality standard, they leave a very low bar for the competitors and so even they (the competitors) do not make huge attempts to improve the audio quality considerably, except for reputable audio brands that have a reputation and a desire to serve the audio community. So, if the audio quality is your concern, find a real audio brand name that makes the pods that will work for your device and enjoy! I t will not be cheap, but I think in the long run it will be worth it due to better quality sound (more enjoyable) and better quality build (last longer). So, this means that the Airpods are not worth it. If however, you prefer something that works well, but is cheaper, be careful of really cheap stuff as some if those will not work properly, or will be poorly made. Just do your homework and fin d what will meet your needs at a reasonable price. This will save you money and it means that the Airpods are not worth it! If you like the brand matched phone and Airpod and feel the price is justified even though it is high, and you can easily afford it, then they are worth it.

Yes, I think they are. If you have an iPhone. They sound pretty good, sure. They have a pretty nifty charging case that keeps them going all day long. They have good microphones so you can actually be understood while on the phone. But the real reason they are worth every penny is ease of use. My AirPods are not the first wireless Bluetooth earbuds I have owned. The lure of wireless listening and talking has convinced me to buy at least two different sets of them in the past. Shortly after receiving them, I stopped using them. Today they are both sitting in a junk drawer with dead batteries. Why? They’re just too inconvenient to use. Pairing and unpairing them every time you wanted to use them was just too much for them to be useful. Apple has solved this. At least for iPhone owners. They added their own secret sauce on top of the Bluetooth to make pairing and unpairing almost instant. When I get a phone call, I answer my iPhone like normal. Once I realize it’s going to take more than a minute or two, I pop an AirPod out of the case and put it in my ear. By the time I have the second one out of the case, my call is already transferred to them. Perfect. And when I’m done and I put them back in the case, my iPhone goes back to using its own speaker and microphone. This may sound like a small thing but it is not. In terms of making Bluetooth earbuds worth using, it is everything.

They are expensive but after using them for four months I find my life is not as easy without them. I lost the left air pod about two weeks ago and while the right one works fine independently. I miss hearing out of both. Ive tried to search for the second one using the Find my AirPods feature but I could not locate it. Yet I know it is in my home. Now it has no power I’m sure and the “find” feature will not work. I hesitate buying a new pair because I think the left one might appear. At one point I will take the dive to buy another pair. I figure I have some type of back up if I lose the right one of a new set. But if I lose the left again, I am in trouble. Apple should sell insurance on these since they are easily misplaced. They work seamlessly with my other Apple products and I never thought I would become as attached to them as I have. After going back to corded headphones I keep snagging the cord in things and they are always in the way. When I had no other alternative to corded headphones I didnt complain. But now going back to the primitive cord is bothersome and I tire of them constantly being pulled out of my ear when I catch it on a zipper, pocket, drawer handle, car hand brake, etc.

Hi, Kaley Clemmons. They are obviously worth it to the millions of people buying them. Whether they are worth it to you is an objective and personal decision nobody but you can make. Walk into your nearest Apple store and try them out for yourself if you aren’t sure. Complete strangers can’t answer this question for you. How long they last is something you can easily find with on Apple’s website, or even on Quora, since it’s already been asked and answered about a thousand times already here. In fact both questions have been asked and answered here many times. Asking duplicate questions like this only creates more work for the rest of us who get to gleefully merge your duplicates. Please stop doing this. Search before asking. From Apple’s website: AirPods deliver an industry-leading 5 hours of listening time — and now up to 3 hours of talk time — all on one charge. And they’re made to keep up with you, thanks to a charging case that holds multiple charges for more than 24 hours of listening time. Need a quick charge? Just put AirPods back in the case for 15 minutes to get up to 3 hours of listening time and 2 hours of talk time. To check the battery, hold the AirPods next to your iPhone or ask Siri “How’s the battery on my AirPods?” More than 24 hr. of battery life with charging case Up to 5 hr. of listening time on one charge Only 15 min. of charging provides up to 3 hours of listening time And before you ask, yes, those are realistic statements, as many people who actually use them (including me) will tell you.

I’m a high school student so I don’t really have that much money to throw around. I purchased the AirPods about a year ago and in my opinion, it’s probably the best purchase I’ve ever made. You really do get what you pay for. Classes are ten times easier to get through when you can easily listen to music or anything of that sort without anyone noticing that you’re wearing them. The sound is good, but not great if I am going to be completely honest with you, but I think the other features make up for that. I’ve dropped my AirPods countless times and they are still as good as new. I also once dropped them in a parking lot and went home, but I used the find my iPhone feature to locate them and get them back. Battery is always a question that I’m asked about and to this day, I’ve never completely run out of battery. Sometimes I go 2–3 days without charging them. TL;DR my recommendation is to buy them. They are 110% worth it.
